##About the package##

[Imputation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imputation_(statistics)) is the process of filling missing values in a dataset with a intelligently reconstructed value.  This R package provides simple methods for imputing a data matrix.  To install, open a R session and issue

```
install.packages("imputation")
```

##Usage##

```
x = matrix(rnorm(100),10,10)
x[1,1] = NA
x[5,8] = NA
x[2,3] = NA
x[7,7] = NA
k = cv.SVDImpute(x)$k
SVDImpute(x, k)
```

##Algorithms##

###Mean Imputation###
Simply fills missing values using the mean of the column.  The mean is the minimizer of squared error loss for i.i.d data

###Persistence Imputation###
For time series data, fill an observation at time t using t-1

###kNN Imputation###
Find neighbors that don't have missing values, and fill using the mean of the neighbors.

###SVD Imputation###
Least squares can be computed even when there is missing data.  The SVD problem can be formulated as minimizing the squared error between a matrix X and its low rank projection X*.  This problem can be solved using alternating least squares, and X* is returned as the imputed matrix.

###SVT Imputation###
[Singular Value Thresholding](http://www-stat.stanford.edu/~candes/svt/papers.html) a la Emmanuel Candes.

###GBM Imputation###
Uses gradient boosting machines, an ensemble of decision trees, to fill missing values.  GBM is particularly powerful because it can handle categorical data as well
